messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@m...> wrote:
> By the way, continuous integration servers (such as
> CruiseControl) would generate a nice report that include
> failed tests along with the list of the changed sources.
> That may not scale well for a massive code change but
> still provide a good help to find a starting point... or
> narrow down list of guilty developers. :-)

Most often a test failure is due to changes made since the last
clean run. Yesterday, however, we had a test fail, in Cruise
Control, while neither the test nor anything it called had been
changed for months.


(Want a clue? Well... Yesterday was the last day of a month; a
boundary condition.)

So we found an edge case, like the "year 2000" issue, where code can
fail due to the passage of time, not just changes to the code.


Generally, however, we find that build failures are caused by
something in the list of changes Cruise Control reports.
